ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got better at writing in a non-analytical, less structured, but still purposeful way.
An ability to understand how writers approach various types of essays and how they structure their work; an appreciation for how to emulate their styles
I learned how to further explore personal narratives.
how to write non-academically but still give actually convincing arguments

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course is strong in its design. I did feel that my class spent too much time discussing in the abstract what the essays were about and not enough time discussing how they were written (the latter being significantly more useful in developing skills as writers), but this was probably more an artifact of my section than of the class itself.
Good discussion environment, fair assessment of abilities

strengths: drafting, workshopping, reading pieces of students essays, reading long-form narrative weaknesses: sometimes the pedagogy (i.e. reading a lot of essays) failed when we had to do a lot in one night and had little time to discuss. I would honestly recommend eliminating the Norton Reader from the course and keeping DFW, and making us print some of the essays --kind of a waste of money and also made the guidelines too strict for the course (i.e. prescribed readings, and a lot were really bad)
Taught very well. No real weaknesses. The readings were interesting and applicable and the essays were fun to write and graded fairly!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who feels confident in his/her analytical writing abilities. Someone who doesn't have a strong background in analytical writing will probably benefit from taking English 114, but anyone who comes from a high school with a strong English department will definitely learn more from English 120.

If you're interested in improving your writing, this class is a must-take. We read some of the most interesting modern essays and talk about them at length. Spending time on constructing your own essays is also very rewarding.

YES! really an incredible WR credit, especially compared to ENGL 114 and 115 (though I havent taken them). workload is daunting at first but I feel like a much stronger writer after having written and edited 5 essays. good readings for most seminars, especially david foster wallace. great teachers
Yes, it was interesting and improved my writing.
